content.title: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia
content.summary: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) is an acquired hemolytic anemia caused by autoantibodies directed against red blood cell surface antigens. It is classified as warm (IgG-mediated, extravascular hemolysis) or cold (IgM-mediated, complement-dependent hemolysis). The direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is diagnostic, and treatment depends on the antibody type.
key_points: Direct Coombs test (DAT) positive is diagnostic
Warm AIHA: IgG antibodies, extravascular hemolysis, treat with steroids
Cold AIHA: IgM antibodies, complement-mediated, cold avoidance first-line
May be idiopathic or secondary to lymphoproliferative disorders, infections, or drugs
Spherocytes on peripheral smear (RBCs lose membrane in spleen)
Avoid packed RBC transfusion unless life-threatening; use extended crossmatch
content.statement: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is characterized by production of autoantibodies against red blood cells, causing premature RBC destruction, diagnosed by positive direct Coombs test, and classified by thermal reactivity of the antibody which determines treatment approach.

explanation.intuition: In AIHA, the immune system mistakes RBCs as foreign and tags them for destruction. Warm antibodies (IgG) work best at body temperature and tag RBCs for splenic macrophages. Cold antibodies (IgM) activate complement at low temperatures, causing intravascular hemolysis when blood flows through cool extremities.
explanation.key_insight: The thermal amplitude of the antibody determines clinical presentation and treatment: Warm AIHA responds to immunosuppression (steroids, rituximab); Cold AIHA requires cold avoidance and may respond to complement inhibitors or anti-CD20 therapy but NOT steroids.
explanation.technical_details: Warm AIHA: IgG binds RBCs at 37°C; Fc portion recognized by splenic macrophages leading to phagocytosis or partial membrane loss (spherocyte formation). Cold agglutinin disease: IgM binds at <37°C, fixes complement (C3b); cells either undergo intravascular lysis or are cleared by hepatic macrophages. Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria: IgG Donath-Landsteiner antibody binds at cold temperatures, lyses at warm temperatures.

definitions_glossary.direct_antiglobulin_test: Coombs test detecting antibodies/complement directly bound to RBC surface; positive in AIHA
definitions_glossary.indirect_antiglobulin_test: Detects antibodies in serum; used for compatibility testing and antibody identification
definitions_glossary.warm_AIHA: AIHA caused by IgG antibodies that bind optimally at 37°C
definitions_glossary.cold_agglutinin_disease: AIHA caused by IgM antibodies that bind optimally at 0-4°C
definitions_glossary.paroxysmal_cold_hemoglobinuria: Rare AIHA caused by biphasic IgG (Donath-Landsteiner antibody)
definitions_glossary.spherocyte: RBC that has lost membrane, appearing small and round without central pallor
definitions_glossary.extravascular_hemolysis: RBC destruction by macrophages in spleen/liver
definitions_glossary.intravascular_hemolysis: RBC destruction within bloodstream with free hemoglobin release
definitions_glossary.complement_fixation: Activation of complement cascade leading to C3b deposition or membrane attack complex
definitions_glossary.thermal_amplitude: Temperature range over which an antibody can bind its antigen
definitions_glossary.secondary_AIHA: AIHA occurring in setting of underlying disease (CLL, SLE, infection)

paroxysmal_cold_hemoglobinuria.mechanism: Binds in cold, activates complement when warmed

required: Hemolytic anemia (elevated LDH, reticulocytes; low haptoglobin)
secondary_causes_workup: CLL and lymphoma screening (flow cytometry, CT)

pharmacologic: Sutimlimab (C1s inhibitor, first targeted therapy for CAD)

transfusion.indication: Severe symptomatic anemia (use warmed blood in cold AIHA)
transfusion.crossmatch: Extended phenotype matching, least incompatible units

definition.@value: An acquired hemolytic anemia caused by autoantibodies directed against red blood cell antigens, diagnosed by positive direct antiglobulin test, and classified as warm or cold based on antibody thermal characteristics

scopeNote.@value: Includes warm AIHA, cold agglutinin disease, and paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria

learning_objectives: Classify AIHA by antibody type and thermal characteristics
Describe treatment approaches for warm vs cold AIHA
Explain why transfusion is challenging in AIHA
clinical_pearls: DAT positive + spherocytes + hemolysis = AIHA until proven otherwise
C3 only on DAT = cold agglutinin disease (steroids won't work)
RBC agglutination in EDTA tube at room temperature = cold agglutinins
Always screen for CLL in elderly patients with AIHA
Rituximab is increasingly first-line alongside steroids in warm AIHA
Sutimlimab is the first FDA-approved drug specifically for cold agglutinin disease
common_misconceptions: All AIHA responds to steroids - cold AIHA does not
Transfusion is contraindicated in AIHA - use when life-threatening, expect reduced survival
Splenectomy works for all AIHA - ineffective in cold AIHA (hepatic/intravascular hemolysis)
